Tourism Ambassador Program
(Question No. 1003)

span.span: asked the Minister for Tourism, in writing, on 8 May 2012:

p.span: In respect of current Tourism Ambassadors under the Tourism Ambassador Program, (a) how many Ambassadors are currently engaged ,(b) does each primarily conduct their work domestically or internationally, (c) is their work voluntary or paid; if the latter, how is payment determined (ie, fixed term, fee per event) and what sum was paid per Ambassador in 2010-11; if under contract, on what date will each contract expire, (d) what costs have each Ambassador incurred (to date) in performing their duties, and (e) what total sum was spent on the Tourism Ambassador Program in 2010-11, and is budgeted to be spent 2011-12.

span.span: The answer to the honourable member

p.span: In respect of current Tourism Ambassadors under the Tourism Ambassador Program:
(a) How many Ambassadors are currently engaged

Tourism Australia (TA) currently has over 160 international and Australian based advocates in its ambassador program, known as the Friends of Australia program (FOA). Ambassadors engaged as part of FOA have committed to help promote Australia without financial payment. See Attachment A.

TA also engages with Australian and international personalities in broader marketing projects. Any activity that a FOA is engaged in where their services go beyond that of their FOA commitment is dealt with as part the broader marketing project they are engaged in.
(b) Does each primarily conduct their work domestically or internationally
FOAs are engaged in opportunities both domestically and internationally free of charge.
Examples of domestic work include but are not limited to:
participating in media interviews and content projects as part of TA's domestic marketing strategy;
providing testimonial content (both written and video) that is distributed via Australia.com, Tourism Australia's You Tube channel and other digital platforms;
blogging and using social networks to share positive stories about Australia.
Examples of international work include but are not limited to:
hosting international media and participating in interviews as part of TA's International Media Hosting Program;
providing testimonial content to be used in advertorials, editorials, digital and broadcast content initiatives;
attending TA related events in key markets, such as G'day LA, press conferences, launch announcements and media briefings.

(c) Is their work voluntary or paid; if the latter, how is payment determined (ie, fixed term, fee per event) and what sum was paid per Ambassador in 2010-11; if under contract, on what date will each contract expire
FOA are not paid for their involvement in the program and advocate about Australia on a voluntary basis.
On occasion, TA does offer paid opportunities for FOAs, where the scope of work is considered to require significant time and effort on behalf of the ambassador. Examples of this include:
A FOA hosting a TA owned television series or major broadcast initiative, other than general editorial coverage
A FOA emceeing an event, such as a press conference or stakeholder event
A FOA appointed as a formal ambassador for a specific campaign, that requires a significant working commitment

In instances where a FOA is paid for their activities, payment is determined as a one off fee per event/ campaign/ opportunity. When a Friend of Australia is involved in activity as part of a marketing campaign (such as a television series or as an ambassador for a specific campaign), this activity is considered beyond their involvement in the FOA program, and is managed and paid as part of the relevant marketing project.
Ambassadors currently under contract include:
Matt Moran is currently under contract for the T-Qual Tick Tour campaign. His contract ends 31/07/2012.
Erica Angyal is an Australian expatriate living in Japan and is under contract for her services as an ambassador until 31/12/2014.
Please see part (d) for payments to FOA.
(d) What costs have each Ambassador incurred (to date) in performing their duties, and
In 2010/11 no payments were made to FOA.
In 2011/12 FOA were paid as follows:
Steve Liebmann emceed 5 Tourism Australia press conferences to date, at a reduced average fee of $2500 (+GST) per event;
Catriona Rowntree emceed 1 Tourism Australia event, at a reduced fee of $1000 (+GST);
Sophie Falkiner emceed 1 Tourism Australia press conference at a reduced fee of $1500 (+GST).
In 2011/12 FOAs engaged in broader marketing activities including the domestic Dream Team promotion, T-Qual Tick Tour and No Leave No Life TV Show were paid as follows:

Tim Ross—paid by Endemol Southern Star (ESS) who produced No Leave No Life season 3. Payment by ESS was for 7 episodes of No Leave No Life season 3, including 7 weeks of filming. Tim Ross was not a FOA until after the series went to air.

Matt Moran—paid a fee of $108,000 for services as T-Qual Tick ambassador and participation in the T-Qual Tick Tour from 22 March – 27 July 2012, including visits to over 52 T-Qual accredited operators.
Bruce Hopkins, Sophie Falkiner, Dave Thornton and Michelle Bridges—paid a combined fee of $62,000 for participating in the Dream Team domestic marketing campaign in 2011.
In Japan, Erica Angyal – paid an annual contract fee for December 2011 – November 2012 of $6250 for marketing activities and an event attendance fee of $2500.
(e) What total sum was spent on the Tourism Ambassador Program in 2010-11, and is budgeted to be spent 2011-12.

In addition to the direct payments outlined in question (D), TA allocates an annual operating budget to support the development of the program. Payments made to FOAs are through the marketing project or event budget, and not as a FOA.

The total budget spent on the FOA program in 2010-11 was $142,000. This included video production, content development, an annual networking event and fees to an external public relations company to manage the program.
The total budget allocated to the FOA program in 2011-12 is $49,500.00. The 2011-12 FOA budget does not include the services of a public relations company, as the program is now managed within TA.
